reviews.review:
You want Half-Life 3? Then do this:

- Don't pay for microtransactions in any game like TF2, CS:GO or Dota 2

- Don't buy Steam Trading Cards

- If you want, don't sell your cards either

- Actually, don't buy or sell anything from the Community Market

- If you want an item from a game, use the original trading and not the market

- Don't craft badges with the trading cards

- Don't buy games on Steam just for the trading cards

- Buy Half-Life games

A very fun twist on the original Half-Life. I'm coming back to all of these games almost 20 years later as an adult.

Opposing Force is the faster, more destructive alternate to Half-Life IMO. Lots of new weapons that are much more damaging, but you also have some enemies towards the end of this game that require it. I'll just say... REALLY GLAD I PLAYED THIS ONE ON EASY.

Overall, it's a much shorter trip through the facility but it never wears out its welcome. There is a "bad ending" mixed into the game somewhere, so keep an eye out for that one, it's actually really cool. Would have definitely been as much of a challenge as the first had I not chickened out to start.

I had a hell of a good time with Half-Life, but ultimately became too frustrating. Easy was still challenging enough for a casual gamer, but allowed me to speed through this game a bit because I mean, come on. This game is great and I'm glad to be here, but I have newer things to play.

Highly recommended for those travelling down memory lane & looking for old PC game challenges!
The definition of a good DLC.

I just bought the Rainbow Six Siege complete eddition on uplay (were boycotting ubi for years) because these days ubisoft somewhat less greedy and intitled than valve corportation! What a crazy world we live in these days. 

Who would of guess that valve corporation will become that unethical micro-gambling piece of wasted human potential? Sure, money is good but video games always have been something more. It is a form of modern art.

At this stage valve corporation doesn't think that video games is a form of art but rather a form of business.

Art can't exist without sacrifice. And current valve employees are unwilling to sacrifice this cash cow in the name of art. 

Valve employees - don't you have enough millions stacked at this point?

Like it!

Para los que hay√°is jugado al Half Life original, decir que la jugabilidad no cambia lo m√°s m√≠nimo. La innovaci√≥n a parte de manejar a otro prota, es que tenemos algunas armas nuevas y/o diferentes.

La ambientaci√≥n es igual, solo que en √©ste hay m√°s escenarios exteriores, muchos militares y m√°s enemigos humanos que en el HL original, los cuales a m√≠ me parecen m√°s dif√≠ciles que los aliens.

La dificultad la puedes ajustar, pero yo soy de los que a m√°s dif√≠cil, mejor. Teniendo en cuenta que puedes guardar donde quieras con el F5, p√≥ntelo en dif√≠cil, de esa manera no podr√°s ir a lo loco y tendr√°s que usar bien tus recursos.

Los gr√°ficos ya son antiguos, as√≠ que si buscas calidad gr√°fica, √©ste no es tu juego. Pero no hay que confundirse, ya que este juego aunque haya envejecido regul√≠n gr√°ficamente, se defender√° perfectamente toda la vida.

*NOTA:  es cierto que pudiendo haber metido el idioma espa√±ol, es un poco ratilla que no los a√±adan a las expansiones, pero sinceramente, he tardado 1 minuto de reloj en meterme en internet y descargar en un zip las traducciones de textos y voces de ambas expansiones, funcionando perfecto y solo teniendo que combinar unas carpetas y archivos.

En definitiva, ambas expansiones a mi me encantan, complementan muy bien el juego y realmente la historia en HL es buena. Esperad al m√≠tico pack de half-life en ofertas y por 5 euros te pillas el HL1 y 2 con todas las expansiones.

[h1] Review [/h1]

Before Gearbox Software was working on games like Brothers in Arms and Borderlands, Gearbox was working with Valve to create expansion packs for Half-Life. The result being Half-Life: Opposing Force. In this expansion you play as Corporal Adrian Shephard, a U.S. Marine sent to Black mesa to silence any witnesses and eliminate Gordon Freeman.

Opposing force adds a bunch of new mechanics in the game and new content including new weapons, characters, new enemies, multiplayer modes and music. The maps however aren't as  memorable as the original game, but the layouts and puzzles are better.

If you enjoyed the original Half-life than you'll like this expansion.

Some great new weapons like the sniper rifle and the alien weapons. Great length for a DLC, a bit longer than Half-Life Blue Shift. The night vision is very cool as well. A lot of new enemies and NPCs.

The only bad things I encountered were some bugs, like the allied soldiers not following you or sudden game crashes.

Neverless a great game you should play.

My favorite of the Goldsrc Half-Lives. A lot better than HL1. Why?

New race! Race X. Got some cool looking and dangerous foes. My favorite just might be the shock troopers.

New weapons, the exotic ones I especially like. Shock roach is a pretty nice gadget for disposing of weak enemies. The teleporter gun is cool too. This time the high caliber pistol is another one, and actually a nice weapon. You can either have it fire fast, with even first shot being inaccurate quite a bit, or fire it slower with laser sight on where it is sniper accurate. The M60 machine gun is really a weapon of destruction. Shame though that there's no Tau cannon. 

Good soundtrack, the tension tracks with military style drumming are memorable.

Armed friendly NPCs, that is alive fellow HECU grunts, are pretty good fighters, although not terribly durable..
Woooorth it !

I found this DLC to be less frustrating than the original Half-Life. The new weapons are also very nice additions to the game. The game was very fun and challenging, though I found the final boss to be very easy. [spoiler]Also, in chapter 6 you can see Gordon Freeman teleport to Xen for the first time (and yes, you can take the portal as well, but you will die for attempting to "create a temporal paradox"), which is pretty cool.[/spoiler] So yeah, definitely play.

This game is an expansion pack to the original Half-Life, It's pretty good. You see the Marines' side of the Black Mesa incident. 

You play as Adrian Shephard who was mysteriously bumped up to the Advanced Training List and is sent to Black Mesa for a clean up operation. Things go wrong and Shephard must fight for his life against Black Ops, Aliens from Xen, and Race X.

I highly recommend you give this a try.
mucho mejor q el blue shift

I recommend this Half-Life add-on, because in general is fun and gives another perspective to the events on the first game. Having said that, in terms of story and narrative i think it is far inferior to its predecessor, even though some details of how Black Mesa incident was handled are given. Half-Life has a twisted mistery aura sorrounding it, Opposing Force is just the exploitation of some elements of the original game like wacky aliens, relentless military men and lots of guns, but no compelling story. Gameplay and game mechanics remain almost the same, except for two new movement mechanics. However gun shots, loud explosion, lots of kills and some annoying issues related to movement are still there.

All the components that made Half-Life such a terrific first-person shooter experience are all here (amazing story, great AI, solid gameplay, scripted scenes, cinematic resonance, multiplayer modes and so on,) but unfortunately, this expansion is hindered by technical issues. Like the original Half-Life revolutionized the FPS genre, Opposing Force has set a new bar when it comes to expansion packs and that‚Äôs an achievement in itself.

Welcome to Opposing Force,you are one of the Marines,playing as Adrian Shephard,your job is to finish off Gordon Freeman,the protagonist of the original Half  Life,but,despite of being a simple premise,the story is much more fun than you can expect,this game has its original maps,new weapons,a likeable character,and new Xen enemies,things that simply were not present in the original Half Life,if you want an experience comparable to Half Life,then you need to play Half Life Opposing Force,now,not everyone can like this game,but alot of pepole(including me) love it,and has a special place in our memories

This is actually the best expansion of Half-Life. Heck, I think it's even better than the original Half-Life.

As a word of warning, keep multiple saves. Sometimes save files get corrupted for some reason. I don't remember getting this bug in the original version that I got years ago but this bug seems to exist for the Steam version.

Anyway, I am recommending this game because it is enjoyable. I like having the military perspective of the Black Mesa situation. 

You also get some new weapons like the Desert Eagle, M249 SAW machine gun, M40A1 sniper rifle, a combat knife, a wrench, and a sci-fi teleportation gun. You also get to use some alien weapons like the shock roach (shoots electricity) and the spore launcher. Both of which are used by the Race X aliens which are different from the Xen aliens you see in the beginning and in other Half-Life games. Finally, you get to use one of those barnacles as a grapple to reach high places assuming there is some biological substance for it to grab onto of course.

The boot camp tutorial level was funny too.

I am wondering when this game will get a new release like the original Half-Life did with Black Mesa Source. They should make one for Blue Shift and Decay too.
Great military fps story line
bon jeux mais il a un bug les solda ne suivre pas il traverse pas les porte je suis bloquer mais bon oui ses un bon jeux

A great expansion pack to Half-Life. It tells the story of the game from one of the military specialists' perspectives. It also adds [spoiler]a new alien race from a different universe[/spoiler], which does feel a bit like it was thrown in there to make things more interesting, but you'll still have fun fighting them. The new weapons are also really fun to use. Opposing Force is about half the length of Half-Life but it ramps up the difficulty much quicker than Half-Life did.

Opposing Force is for people who enjoyed the gameplay of HL1 and are looking for seconds, preferably with wackier weapons and a grappling hook.

I played original Half-Life back in the day, but not the expansions.  So when I picked up the original in a nostalgia rush, I decided to fill in that particular omission.  So I came to this with nostalgia for the original game and all its flaws, but not this iteration.  And I enjoyed it; I think it's inferior to the original, but as an expansion that's expected.

The gameplay is the main strength here.  The new weapons show variety and creativity.  The two melee weapons are arguably better than Gordon's iconic crowbar; at the least, they give more depth to close combat.  The alien weapons are where things get really creative, and also creepily cute.  The Shock Roach is more satisfying than the Hive Hand ever was; you lose the ability to shoot round corners, but the damage feels better and you gain the ability to accidentally suicide in water.  The Spore Launcher offers interesting reloading strategies and bouncing projectiles that reward skill, plus amusing idle animations.  The Displacer Cannon rewards experimentation. Lastly, the Barnacle "grappling hook" enhances the overall experience by adding a third dimension of mobility.  

The new enemies are nice to see, though I don't think they add anything tactically.  To me, they fill roles similar to the Xen aliens in HL1.  There are some good set-pieces, such as the conflict in the sewers.  The presence of squad mates is fun, though it is limited by the dated AI.

The story is a bit of a trickier proposition.  While the creators clearly put a lot of effort into the plot and how it is told, it doesn't feel quite as polished as the original.  A bigger problem, perhaps, is that nothing here is directly mentioned in later games.  Skipping this doesn't affect your enjoyment of the larger Half-Life narrative, hence my recommendation above.
Very good game. Play since 2002.

Muey bueno

This expansion to the original Half Life puts you in the shoes of shepard, a Marine sent to Black Mesa to detain Gordon Freeman. But as anyone who has played the original knows, anything that can go wrong will go wrong, and things go to hell pretty quickly. The main draw of this is a new capaign, new areas, new weapons, and some new mechanics like a grappling hook and squad commands. The game succeeds in new areas and new weapons, with a much needed sniper rifle and hevay machine gun, as well as a few alien weapons rounding out Shepard's arsenal. I'm not sure how successful it is with the new mechanics though. The grappling hook, made from a detached Barnacle, works very well, but rope climbing and swinging feels wonky at best. Squad AI is extremely basic and they frequently get in the way more than they help, but they're useful if for no other reason than drawing enemy fire while you blast away at the myriad creatures you'll be facing, including some now aliens and Black Ops soldiers who have been sent in to clean this messy situation up. Not perfect, but pretty solid, even if the ending boss fight feels basic and the ending itself underwhelming.

Troche powtarzany ten sam schemat, bardziej liczylem na cos w stylu zabijaniu zakladnikow itd. No ale da sie przymnkac na to oczko + to chyba najtrudniejsza z czesci hl1. 1/2 jedynki + widzimy GFreemana raz chyba wiec no 6/10.

Half Life: Opposing Force is the true expansion pack to the original title. The single player campaign delivers in terms of action and storyline satisfaction. It also delivers in terms of new items and enemies added to the game, which is where I feel Blue Shift fell short. If you liked the orginal Half-Life, you will love Opposing Force.
This expansion is what every expansion should be.
